transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Hi, this is Arjun calling from MongoDB. Is this Zhi, the Director of IT at Acme Corp.?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah, this is Zhi. How can I help you?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Thanks, Zhi. I know you're busy—I'll be brief. I saw Acme Corp. recently kicked off a major migration initiative. Can you share what prompted that shift?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah, sure. We’re trying to modernize, basically. Our current stack is a bit rigid. Snowflake's great for analytics, but transactional workloads? Not so much.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: That makes sense. A lot of retail companies are running into that wall. Is flexibility for real-time applications one of your goals with this migration?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah, we want to personalize customer experiences, maybe offer real-time inventory. That stuff.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Exactly where MongoDB Atlas shines. It’s built for those transactional, fast-moving use cases. Have you considered using something like a document database alongside Snowflake?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: I’ve heard of MongoDB, but... Is it really that different? Also, honestly—pricing is a big concern. We’re already investing a lot into this migration.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Totally fair. Atlas offers a pay-as-you-go model, so you only pay for what you use. Actually, for retail workloads, customers often see lower TCO compared to traditional SQL setups because scaling up and down is seamless.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Okay, but the migration itself is risky. We can’t afford downtime, and my team’s used to SQL. I worry about ramp-up time and, um, vendor lock-in.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah, absolutely—migration risk is top of mind for everyone. Atlas actually has built-in migration tooling and we see a lot of customers running hybrid for a while, with SQL and MongoDB side by side.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: And on vendor lock-in—MongoDB is multi-cloud. You can run workloads on AWS, GCP, or Azure. You're not stuck in one ecosystem, which gives you options.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: That’s good to know. Security and compliance are also always on our minds, especially handling payment data.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Of course. Atlas is fully compliant with SOC 2, GDPR, PCI DSS—all the standards you’d expect. Plus, encryption at rest and in motion is default.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Hmm, okay. I’d just need to see a clearer business case and migration roadmap for Acme before I bring this to my team.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: That’s exactly what I’d like to help with. How about we set up a call with your team and one of our solution architects? We can walk through your current workloads and map out a pilot, no commitment.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Uh, yeah, that sounds reasonable. Can you send me some available times for next week? I’ll loop in my app dev lead.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Absolutely, Zhi. I’ll send over some slots this afternoon. Thanks for your time today—and I’m looking forward to diving deeper.
